label: HH1

text: Quarterly Highlights, Q2 2022
label: HH1

text: Quarterly Highlights: April - June 2022
label: HH1

text: Highlights, Q2 2022:
label: HH1

text: Reported COVID-19 cases in Second Quarter 2022 (Q2 2022) fell by 71 percent compared to First Quarter 2022.
label: BODY

text: This reported decrease is likely due in part to reduced testing and monitoring, meaning fewer cases are
label: BODY

text: detected. Despite the overall reduction, reported global cases rose throughout June driven by increases in the
label: HH1

text: Eastern Mediterranean, Europe, South-East Asia, and the Americas. The Omicron variant continues to comprise
label: HH1

text: the majority (94 percent) of sequenced cases, including the Omicron sub-variants BA.4 and BA.5 which appear
label: HH1

text: more capable of evading immunity from vaccination or past infection. Countries in the Global Humanitarian
label: HH1

text: Overview (GHO) comprised 8 and 14 percent of global cases and deaths respectively in Q2 2022, reporting 4.6
label: H4

text: million cases and 23,000 deaths.
label: HH1

text: WHO data reveals between 597,000 to 2.2 million excess deaths attributable to COVID-19 occurred in countries
label: HH1

text: with humanitarian response plans (HRP) between 1 January 2020 and 31 December 2021, significantly more
label: HH1

text: deaths from COVID-19 than oﬀicially reported. This data highlights the steep toll of the pandemic across
label: HH1

text: humanitarian settings.
label: HH1

text: Total vaccine doses delivered to HRP countries fell by half in Q2 2022 compared to Q1 2022. Eight HRP
label: BODY

text: countries received no doses this quarter, including Burundi, CAR, El Salvador, Libya, Niger, Ukraine, Venezuela,
label: HH1

text: and Yemen. Of these, Burundi, Niger, and Yemen are yet to vaccinate more than 5 percent of populations.
label: BODY

text: COVAX was the largest supplier of doses to HRP countries in May and June.
label: HH1

text: Projected economic growth declined further in 17 HRP countries from January to June 2022 due to the
label: BODY

text: compounding eﬀects of the COVID-19 pandemic and the secondary impacts of the war in Ukraine. Expected
label: HH1

text: GDP growth in 2023 has been reduced by a percentage point or more for 8 HRP countries, with Mozambique
label: BODY

text: (-3.6), Sudan (-3), and Niger (-2.3) facing the steepest reductions in expected growth. Humanitarian settings
label: HH1

text: also face significant debt risks, with four HRP countries – Chad, Mozambique, Somalia, and Sudan – currently
label: BODY

text: in debt distress.
label: HH1

text: Fourteen immunization campaigns continue to be postponed due to COVID-19 in Q2 2022, impacting more than
label: HH1

text: 52 million people across 13 GHO countries. The postponement of these campaigns, targeting diseases like
label: HH1

text: yellow fever, measles, cholera, and polio, increase the risk of secondary diseases spreading across
label: HH1

text: humanitarian settings, with outbreaks of diseases like measles occurring in Q2 2022.
label: HH1

text: New data from UN Women reveals that 26 HRP countries had gender sensitive pandemic policies, with seven
label: BODY

text: gender sensitive policies implemented on average.  Colombia implemented the most (31), followed by
label: HH1

text: Honduras (17) and oPt (16). Iraq and Libya had none. Despite implementing gender sensitive COVID-19
label: HH1

text: policies, the disproportionate impact of the COVID-19 pandemic – such as increased violence or economic
label: HH1

text: fallout – on women and girls remains felt across HRP countries.
label: HH1

text: UNDP & UN Women, ‘COVID-19 Global Gender Response Tracker.’ Available at: https://data.undp.org/gendertracker/
label: BODY

text: Sources: Epidemiological Update (World Health Organization, Our World in Data, Media sources); Vaccine update (Gavi, Our World in Data, UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, Media
label: BODY

text: sources); Secondary Impacts (UNESCO, OCHA, IMF, World Bank, Media sources); Funding Update (OCHA) as of 1 July 2022. For feedback, please contact: centrehumdata@un.org.
label: BODY

label: TITLE

text: COVID-19 Data Explorer: Global Humanitarian Operations
label: HH1

text: Quarterly Highlights, Q2 2022
label: HH1

text: 1. Epidemiological Update
label: HH1

text: Global reported COVID-19 cases in the Second Quarter 2022 (Q2 2022) declined by 71 percent, falling from 196 million
label: BODY

text: to 57 million. This decline, however, likely reflects reduced testing and monitoring meaning fewer cases are detected.
label: BODY

text: Even with testing scaled back, and despite the overall drop during Q2, reported COVID-19 cases rose in June globally for three
label: BODY

text: consecutive weeks. Regional increases in the Eastern Mediterranean, Europe, South-East Asia, and the Americas drove this
label: BODY

text: increase.  This spike in reported COVID-19 may signal a larger increase in COVID-19 transmission cases beyond that reflected
label: BODY

text: in reported figures, given lower rates of testing. The weekly rate of deaths remained stable globally, although increases in
label: BODY

text: deaths typically lag cases and thus could rise in coming weeks.
label: BODY

text: The Omicron variant comprises most COVID-19 cases (94 percent), with Omicron sub-variants BA.4 and BA.5
label: HH1

text: increasingly represented within sequenced samples. These two sub-variants appear more capable of evading immunity
label: HH1

text: from vaccination or past infection. BA.4 and BA.5 were classified as Variants of Concern by the European Centre for Disease
label: BODY

text: Protection in May 2022, and they are currently driving surges in COVID-19 cases in countries like the USA.
label: BODY

text: Countries in the Global Humanitarian Overview (GHO) comprised 8 percent and 14 percent of global cases and deaths
label: H4

text: respectively in Q2 2022, reporting 4.6 million deaths and 23,000 deaths. Of these 282,000 cases and 2,670 deaths
label: BODY

text: occurred in countries with Humanitarian Response Plans (HRPs). Across HRPs, Burundi (11 percent) and Guatemala (9
label: HH1

text: percent) reported the largest increases in cases this quarter, while Guatemala (7 percent) and DRC (3 percent) reported the
label: BODY

text: largest increase in deaths. Humanitarian settings continue to face significant barriers to testing and surveillance, meaning
label: BODY

text: many COVID-19 cases and deaths may go unreported.
label: BODY

text: Figure 1 & 2. COVID-19 cases in Q2 in GHO and HRP countries
label: BODY

text: (as of 30 June 2022)
label: BODY

text: WHO, ‘Weekly epidemiological update on COVID-19,’ 29 June 2022. Available at: https://www.who.int/publications/m/item/weekly-epidemiological-up
label: BODY

text: date-on-covid-19---29-june-2022
label: BODY

text: ECDC. 13 May 2022. Available at: https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/en/news-events/epidemiological-update-sars-cov-2-omicron-sub-lineages-ba4-and-ba5
label: BODY

text: Sources: Epidemiological Update (World Health Organization, Our World in Data, Media sources); Vaccine update (Gavi, Our World in Data, UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, Media
label: BODY

text: sources); Secondary Impacts (UNESCO, OCHA, IMF, World Bank, Media sources); Funding Update (OCHA) as of 1 July 2022. For feedback, please contact: centrehumdata@un.org.

text: COVID-19 Data Explorer: Global Humanitarian Operations
label: HH1

text: Quarterly Highlights, Q2 2022
label: HH1

text: Figure 3 & 4. COVID-19 deaths in Q2 in GHO and HRP countries
label: BODY

text: (as of 30 June 2022)
label: BODY

text: The pandemic exacted a greater toll on humanitarian settings than oﬀicially reported, with 597,000 to 2.2 million
label: BODY

text: excess deaths attributable to COVID-19 occurring across HRP countries according to WHO data. This is significantly more
label: BODY

text: than reported in oﬀicial figures. Low rates of testing and surveillance masked initial reporting, but new data from WHO and
label: BODY

text: other sources identify additional excess deaths likely attributable to COVID-19 occurring between 1 January 2020 and 31
label: BODY

text: December 2021.
label: BODY

text: Furthermore, newly released data collected across 25 low- and middle-income countries finds that the risk of dying from
label: BODY

text: COVID-19 was twice as high in lower-income countries compared to high-income ones.  This is likely due to low-income
label: BODY

text: countries having less access to vaccinations, weaker health care systems, more multigenerational households, and less ability
label: BODY

text: to work from home. HRP countries included in this study are Colombia, Ethiopia, and Mozambique.
label: BODY

text: Figure 5. COVID-19 excess deaths in HRP countries
label: BODY

text: (as of 30 June 2022)
label: BODY

text: WHO, ‘Global excess deaths associated with COVID-19 (modelled estimates),’ 20 May 2021. Available at: https://www.who.int/data/sets/global-excess-
label: BODY

text: deaths-associated-with-covid-19-modelled-estimates
label: BODY

text: Levin, A. T. et al. BMJ Glob. Health 7, e008477 (2022).
label: BODY

text: Sources: Epidemiological Update (World Health Organization, Our World in Data, Media sources); Vaccine update (Gavi, Our World in Data, UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, Media
label: BODY

text: sources); Secondary Impacts (UNESCO, OCHA, IMF, World Bank, Media sources); Funding Update (OCHA) as of 1 July 2022. For feedback, please contact: centrehumdata@un.org.
label: BODY

text: COVID-19 Data Explorer: Global Humanitarian Operations
label: HH1

text: Quarterly Highlights, Q2 2022
label: HH1

text: 2. COVID-19 Vaccination Update
label: HH1

text: Delivered COVID-19 vaccination doses declined overall in Q2 2022, falling by approximately half (86.7 million)
label: HH1

text: compared to Q1 2022 (156.2 million). Eight HRP countries received no doses this quarter, including Burundi, CAR, El
label: BODY

text: Salvador, Libya, Niger, Ukraine, Venezuela, and Yemen.
label: BODY

text: Figure 6. Total doses delivered by month, by funding source
label: BODY

text: (as of 30 June 2022)
label: BODY

text: COVAX supplied the majority of doses in May (54 percent) and June (54 percent), while unknown sources (51 percent)
label: BODY

text: and COVAX (49 percent) supplied the majority of doses in April. Unknown sources are likely doses delivered through
label: BODY

text: bilateral agreements with details not yet publicly available.
label: BODY

text: Figure 7. Vaccines delivered by recipient country
label: BODY

text: (as of 30 June 2022)
label: BODY

text: Sources: Epidemiological Update (World Health Organization, Our World in Data, Media sources); Vaccine update (Gavi, Our World in Data, UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, Media
label: BODY

text: sources); Secondary Impacts (UNESCO, OCHA, IMF, World Bank, Media sources); Funding Update (OCHA) as of 1 July 2022. For feedback, please contact: centrehumdata@un.org.
label: BODY

text: COVID-19 Data Explorer: Global Humanitarian Operations
label: HH1

text: Quarterly Highlights, Q2 2022
label: HH1

text: Thirteen HRP countries are yet to vaccinate 10 percent of populations, with Cameroon, South Sudan, Yemen, DRC,
label: BODY

text: Haiti, and Burundi yet to vaccinate 5 percent of populations. Low vaccination leaves humanitarian settings vulnerable to
label: BODY

text: future surges and new variants. Even in settings where doses have been delivered, there remain barriers to administration
label: BODY

text: including weak healthcare systems, vaccine hesitancy, compounding crises, and transport issues. Yemen, Somalia, Syria,
label: BODY

text: Chad, South Sudan, DRC, and Burundi are yet to administer more than one-third of delivered doses.
label: BODY

text: Since the end of Q1, the overall vaccination rate across the AMC92 – the 92 lower-income countries eligible for
label: BODY

text: financing support through COVAX to access vaccines – has increased from 40 percent to 47 percent, whereas the
label: BODY

text: average vaccination rate in the 34 countries for concerted support has increased from 7 to 10 percent. The COVID-19
label: BODY

text: Vaccine Delivery Partnership has been supporting the AMC92 countries since January 2022 in accelerating vaccine delivery
label: BODY

text: with a focus on the 34 countries at or below 10 percent vaccination coverage in January 2022. At the end of Q1, 19 countries
label: BODY

text: were at or below 10 percent coverage which has dropped slightly to 18 countries by the end of Q2. Of those 18 countries, 14
label: BODY

text: face ongoing humanitarian emergencies, highlighting the challenges and complexities associated with vaccine delivery in a
label: BODY

text: context of fragile health systems, competing health and humanitarian priorities, and significant logistical challenges. These
label: BODY

text: countries continue to exhibit low or flatlining vaccination rates, highlighting the need for more tailored approaches, including
label: BODY

text: closer engagement with humanitarian partners on the ground to support vaccine delivery.
label: BODY

text: Figure 8. Population coverage by delivery and admin by HRP country
label: BODY

text: (as of 30 June 2022)
label: BODY

text: More than 868 million in combined vaccine financing was approved by the World Bank (850 million) and GAVI’s Country
label: BODY

text: Delivery Support (18.5 million) in Q2 2022, reaching eight GHO countries. This is a significant increase from total vaccine
label: BODY

text: financing approved in Q1 2022, during which 257.8 million was approved for eight GHO countries. Türkiye received the most
label: BODY

text: (500 million) followed by Ethiopia (195 million) and Costa Rica (120 million). These funds will support vaccine roll-out and
label: BODY

text: help strengthen national healthcare system preparedness and response.
label: BODY

text: Sources: Epidemiological Update (World Health Organization, Our World in Data, Media sources); Vaccine update (Gavi, Our World in Data, UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, Media
label: BODY

text: sources); Secondary Impacts (UNESCO, OCHA, IMF, World Bank, Media sources); Funding Update (OCHA) as of 1 July 2022. For feedback, please contact: centrehumdata@un.org.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: 3. Secondary Impacts
label: HH1

text: Economic Eﬀects
label: BODY

text: Projected economic growth declined further in 17 HRP countries from January to June 2022, with the compounding
label: BODY

text: eﬀects of the COVID-19 pandemic and the secondary impacts of the war in Ukraine globally setting back GDP growth,
label: BODY

text: recovery of incomes to pre-pandemic levels, and poverty reduction.  The pandemic left the world more vulnerable to the
label: BODY

text: secondary economic shocks now stemming from the war in Ukraine, including rising food and fuel prices and inflation. As of
label: BODY

text: June 2022, global growth is expected to fall from 5.7 percent in 2021 to 2.9 percent in 2022, a growth rate 1.2 percent lower
label: BODY

text: than that predicted in January 2022. Global growth will likely be dampened through 2024 due to the lingering eﬀects of the
label: BODY

text: pandemic and disruptions from the war. The World Bank predicts several years of above-average inflation and below-average
label: BODY

text: growth. In 40 percent of developing economies, real income per capita will remain below pre-COVID-19 levels in 2023. Of the
label: BODY

text: 21 HRPs for which data is available, 17 face lower projected real GDP growth for 2022 and/or 2023 compared to growth
label: BODY

text: predictions made in January 2022. Possible lockdowns, transport delays, or industry closures remain a downside risk to
label: BODY

text: global economies.
label: BODY

text: World Bank, ‘Global Economic Prospects,’ June 2022.
label: BODY

text: Sources: Epidemiological Update (World Health Organization, Our World in Data, Media sources); Vaccine update (Gavi, Our World in Data, UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, Media
label: BODY

text: sources); Secondary Impacts (UNESCO, OCHA, IMF, World Bank, Media sources); Funding Update (OCHA) as of 1 July 2022. For feedback, please contact: centrehumdata@un.org.
label: BODY

text: Millions $
label: BODY

text: COVID-19 Data Explorer: Global Humanitarian Operations
label: HH1

text: Quarterly Highlights, Q2 2022
label: HH1

text: Figure 10. Growth projections in June 2023 for HRPs, revised from January 2022
label: BODY

text: (as of 30 June 2022)
label: BODY

text: Expected GDP growth in 2023 has been reduced by a percentage point or more for 8 HRP countries, with Mozambique
label: BODY

text: (-3.6), Sudan (-3), and Niger (-2.3) facing the steepest reductions in expected growth. Compounding crises – including
label: BODY

text: climate change, ongoing eﬀects of the COVID-19 pandemic, conflict and unrest, rising food and fuel prices, and food insecurity
label: BODY

text: all contribute to lower economic growth in these settings. Future COVID-19 surges or new variants could further undermine
label: BODY

text: economic growth by increasing uncertainty and causing shipping delays. HRP countries are particularly vulnerable due to low
label: BODY

text: rates of vaccination, limited access to therapeutics, and weakened healthcare systems. Projected 2022 GDP growth increased
label: BODY

text: in six HRP countries, however, including Iraq and Nigeria, in part because they are oil exporting economies and thus benefit
label: BODY

text: from rising commodity prices in recent months.
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian settings also face significant debt risks, with four HRP countries – Chad, Mozambique, Somalia, and
label: HH1

text: Sudan – currently in debt distress. An additional seven are at high risk of debt distress. Debt servicing payments were
label: BODY

text: paused during the COVID-19 pandemic, resuming in 2022 right as interest rates began to increase. This makes debt more
label: BODY

text: expensive and less sustainable for humanitarian settings. Wealthy countries pledged in 2021 to reallocate USD 100 billion in
label: BODY

text: Special Drawing Rights to lower-income countries. At present, there are pledges to reallocate USD 60 billion.
label: BODY

text: Routine Immunization & Health
label: BODY

text: Fourteen immunization campaigns continue to be postponed due to COVID-19 in Q2 2022, impacting more than 52
label: BODY

text: million people across 13 GHO countries. The postponement of these campaigns, targeting diseases like yellow fever,
label: HH1

text: measles, cholera, and polio, increase the risk of secondary diseases spreading across humanitarian settings.
label: BODY

text: Measles cases, for instance, spiked by 79 percent in the first two months of 2022 compared to 2021. This is due to routine
label: BODY

text: immunization disruption caused by the pandemic.  HRP countries, according to April 2022 data, are most impacted, with
label: BODY

text: Devex, ‘Opinion: Ukraine conflict shows urgency of SDR reallocation for Africa,’ 24 May 2022. Available at: https://www.devex.com/news/opinion-ukraine-
label: BODY

text: conflict-shows-urgency-of-sdr-reallocation-for-africa-103279
label: BODY

text: WHO & UNICEF, ‘UNICEF and WHO warn of perfect storm of conditions for measles outbreaks, aﬀecting children,’ 27 April 2022. Available at: https://
label: BODY

text: www.who.int/news/item/27-04-2022-unicef-and-who-warn-of--perfect-storm--of-conditions-for-measles-outbreaks--aﬀecting-children
label: BODY

text: Sources: Epidemiological Update (World Health Organization, Our World in Data, Media sources); Vaccine update (Gavi, Our World in Data, UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, Media
label: BODY

text: sources); Secondary Impacts (UNESCO, OCHA, IMF, World Bank, Media sources); Funding Update (OCHA) as of 1 July 2022. For feedback, please contact: centrehumdata@un.org.
label: BODY

text: COVID-19 Data Explorer: Global Humanitarian Operations
label: HH1

text: Quarterly Highlights, Q2 2022
label: HH1

text: Somalia, Yemen, Afghanistan, Nigeria, and Ethiopia reporting the most measles cases.  Pakistan is currently experiencing a
label: BODY

text: surge in wild polio cases.  Disruptions to routine immunization caused by the COVID-19 pandemic are another compounding
label: BODY

text: factor contributing to polio’s spread in Pakistan. In April 2020, more than 40 million children across Pakistan missed their
label: BODY

text: polio vaccination after the cancellation of an immunization campaign, with subsequent disruptions persisting throughout the
label: BODY

text: pandemic.  National healthcare systems must continue to be strengthened, both to manage COVID-19 long-term and to
label: BODY

text: absorb increased cases of secondary diseases due to pandemic related disruptions of routine immunization.
label: BODY

text: Gender Update
label: BODY

text: New data from UN women reveals that 26 HRP countries had gender sensitive pandemic policies, with seven gender
label: BODY

text: sensitive policies implemented on average.  The refers to policies adopted at the national level that directly address
label: BODY

text: challenges which uniquely or disproportionately aﬀect women and girls, including violence against women and girls (96
label: BODY

text: policies), women’s economic security (94 policies), or unpaid care work (3 policies). For instance, a policy addressing women’s
label: BODY

text: economic security may target women to receive household cash transfers or prioritize for benefits a subset of workers in
label: BODY

text: which women are significantly overrepresented. Colombia implemented the most gender sensitive policies (31), followed by
label: BODY

text: Honduras (17) and oPt (16). Iraq and Libya had none. Only three countries – Burundi, oPt, and Ukraine – implemented policies
label: BODY

text: directly supporting unpaid care. Women took on a greater burden of unpaid caregiving, including caring for sick relatives
label: BODY

text: during the pandemic. Failing to support this labor disadvantages women and undermines their empowerment.
label: BODY

text: Figure 11. Gender polices on COVID-19, HRPs
label: BODY

text: (as of 30 June 2022)
label: BODY

text: COVID-19 Data Explorer: Global Humanitarian Operations
label: HH1

text: Quarterly Highlights, Q2 2022
label: HH1

text: Despite implementing gender sensitive COVID-19 policies, the disproportionate impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on
label: HH1

text: women and girls remains felt across HRP countries. The pandemic eroded progress on gender-based violence,
label: HH1

text: economic empowerment, education, and healthcare. COVID-19 and its secondary eﬀects left women and girls in a worse
label: BODY

text: position than before the pandemic and increased vulnerability to compounding crises, such as food insecurity or conflict. The
label: BODY

text: pandemic set back progress on domestic violence, with the percent of respondents who believe there are acceptable
label: BODY

text: circumstances to hit a partner increasing by 2 percentage points to 19 percent, according to a 20-country survey.   Women’s
label: BODY

text: economic security also remains at risk. Globally, women’s poverty continues to increase, with more women in poverty than
label: BODY

text: men.  Over 11 million girls remain at risk of not returning to school, reducing their employment and earning opportunities
label: BODY

text: and increasing the risk of early marriage and pregnancy.  Many women and girls also lost access to reproductive care as
label: BODY

text: healthcare systems were strained by COVID-19, contributing to maternal mortality, unwanted pregnancies, disease, and
label: BODY

text: school dropouts. Global estimates suggest that the pandemic caused a 37 percent increase in maternal deaths.  Across Latin
label: BODY

text: America and the Caribbean, 1 in 4 girls did not have access to family planning services.  As data remains limited, the full
label: BODY

text: repercussions of the pandemic on women and girls may not be known for years to come.
label: BODY

text: 4. Funding Update
label: HH1

text: At the end of Q2 2022, 22 percent of total humanitarian financing needs (46.35 billion total GHO) are met. Thirteen HRP
label: BODY

text: countries have received more than 20 percent of funding, Libya (45.7 percent), Central African Republic (38.7 percent), and
label: BODY

text: Afghanistan (34.4 percent). The Ukraine flash appeal, which supersedes the HRP, has received 78.2 percent of required
label: BODY

text: funding. Top doners in 2022 to date include the USA (48.5 percent), the European Commission (6.8 percent), and Germany (5
label: BODY

text: percent).
label: BODY

text: ‘The Levers of Change Gender Equality Attitudes Study 2022. 20 June 2022.’ Available at: https://www.unstereotypealliance.org/en/resources/research-
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY
